import itertools

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

from scipy.stats import ttest_1samp, shapiro, levene, ttest_ind, mannwhitneyu, pearsonr, spearmanr, kendalltau, \
    f_oneway, kruskal
from statsmodels.stats.proportion import proportions_ztest

source.da844381: print(f"Average purchase for control group: {df_control.Purchase.mean()} " f"\nAverage purchase for test group: {df_test.Purchase.mean()}")
source.345d9722:
#The Shapiro-Wilk test to check variables normally distributed

# Assumption of normal distribution
# H0: variables are normally distributed.
# H1: variables are not normally distributed.

test_stat, pvalue = shapiro(df_control["Purchase"])
print('Test Stat = %.4f, p-value = %.4f' % (test_stat, pvalue))

test_stat, pvalue = shapiro(df_test["Purchase"])
print('Test Stat = %.4f, p-value = %.4f' % (test_stat, pvalue))
source.53d3c0d0:
#Levene’s Test for Equality of Variances

# H0: the population variances of group control and test are equal
# H1: the population variances of group control and test are not equal

test_stat, pvalue = levene(df_control["Purchase"],df_test["Purchase"])

print('Test Stat = %.4f, p-value = %.4f' % (test_stat, pvalue))
source.f07df4d6:
#Independent Two-sample t Test

test_stat, pvalue = ttest_ind(df_control["Purchase"],df_test["Purchase"])

print('Test Stat = %.4f, p-value = %.4f' % (test_stat, pvalue))

#create purchase per click variable

df_test["PurcClick"]=df_test["Purchase"]/df_test["Click"]

print(df_test.PurcClick.mean())

plt.title("Purchase Comparasion")
plt.xlabel("Purchase")
plt.ylabel("Average")

source.4a363865:
To observe more detailed.We will analyze purchase per click


* H0: M1 = M2 (There is not statistical difference between average purchase per click of control and test group.)
* H1: M1 != M2 (There is statistical difference between average purchase per click of control and test group.)
source.d9e3977b: p-value is less than 0.05. Therefore we can reject H0 hypothesis.There is statistical difference between average purchase per click of control and test group.
source.b6005be7: p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore we can not reject H0 hypothesis.The population variances of group control and test are equal
source.489a908e:
A/B Testing

Business Problem

One of websites recently introduced a new type of bid, average bidding, as an alternative way to the current type of bidding called maximum bidding. One of our clients decided to test this new feature and would like to do an A/B test to see if averagebidding converts more than maximumbidding.We will analyze the problem using statistical tests and share our observations and suggestions with our customers.

Dataset

In this dataset, which includes the website information of our client , there is information such as the number of advertisements that users see and click, as well as earnings information from here. There are two separate datasets, the control and test groups. IMPRESSION: Count of Customer's Ad views CLICK: Count of click on Ads PURCHASE: Count of Customer's purchase EARNING: Earning of all purchase
source.01c30a71: p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore we can not reject H0 hypothesis.Variables are normally distributed.
source.5e314bf6: p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore we can not reject H0 hypothesis.There is not statistical difference between average purchase of control and test group.
source.8c58eff7: p-value is greater than 0.05. Therefore we can not reject H0 hypothesis.The population variances of group control and test are equal
source.2fca842e: p-value is less than 0.05. Therefore we can reject H0 hypothesis.Variables are not normally distributed.
source.864c5859: In the comparison between the control and test groups, it was observed that the average conversion and the average conversion return per click increased. It is recommended to repeat the test to confirm these increases statistically by extending the observation period.
source.c9c291c1:
We will check statistical difference between average purchase of control and test group.

* H0: M1 = M2 (There is not statistical difference between average purchase of control and test group.)
* H1: M1 != M2 (There is statistical difference between average purchase of control and test group.)
